element_texts.text:
Trip to the Far West
Joseph Sumner
1856

Trip to the Far West
1856 January 11th
Started from Boston at 8 1/2 O'clock A.M. and reached Springfield 98 miles from Boston at 12 O'clock 'M. Took dinner and waited 2 hours for the Express train from the West at 2 0'clock, we started on and arrived at Albany about 8 O'clock in the evening. stopped at the Delevan House had very good accomodations being 200 miles from home and somewhat fatigued I retired at 9 1/2 0'clock P.M.
Saturday Jany 12th
Started from Albany at 7? 1/4 O'clock A. M. and rode to Syracuse 348 miles from Boston here we stopped half an hour for dinner at 1 1/4 O'clock P.M. started for Rochester reached this place at 5 O'clock P.M. here we changed cars for Niagara Falls. arrived at this place at 8 1/4 O'clock in the evening in the midst of a Snow Storm. Stopped at the Clarindon House? which is opposite the Depot and a very fair House but not the first class had a very good room and retired at 9 O'clock 505 miles from Boston
Sunday Jany 13th
Snow has fallen during the night to the depth of 2 feet on the level. That spoils my prospects of pleasure for this day. I had anticipated taking a fine view of the Falls and Suspension Bridge but now I must content myself with reading or almost anything to wear away the time. P.M. it snows yet and the prospect of being weather bound is rather too good to suit a fellow 500 miles from home among strangers. 7? O'clock tired enough of lounging about and go to bed to drown uneasiness and seek rest in balmy sleep.
Monday Jany 14th
Arose at 7? O'clock and took breakfast. and started out for a walk in the snow. went down as far toward the falls as I could, just in sight of the rapids. had to give up seeing

12
the Falls from this point. went up to the Cataract House which is the crack House here now back to the Clarendon House to wait for for the Train for Suspension Bridge. Snows hard. Whew! 2 O'clock P.M. started for the Bridge which is 2 miles from Niagara Depot. Paid toll unclear and went over into Canada to see the Great Western Depot. "Small Fry" compared with Buildings of the same kind in Massachusetts. The Bridge is worth seeing. it is 800 feet long supported by 4 wire cables 10 inches in diameter braced. and stayed in all directions and fastened over Towers built of Stone about 80 feet high into rock at a depth of 20 to 35 feet. the cars passed over me on the Bridge without much motion. or jar. a very little crackling noise was all that reminded me that a Train was passing. standing on the Bridge looking down 245 feet into the Niagara which roars like Thunder in it's restless tossings over the rocks below inclines to reflection on the great and good Being who holds the Universe in his Almighty hand. and the Bridge add another tribute to the genius of Man before whose power almost every obstacle seems to vanish. 4 O'clock P.M. walk up the Rail Road and get a very good view of the Falls at a distance of about half a mile. which is the nearest I can get at this time the snow being 3 feet deep on the level and no prospect of a road being opened for a week and I cannot wait so long. 8 O'clock P.M. conclude to go West tomorrow morning if it does not snow again tonight. hope it will not for I have stayed here housed up long enough.
Tuesday Jany 15th
Start from the Bridge at 11 O'clock A.M. on the Great Western broad gauge? Railway. Cars filled with "Bloody Dutchmen" "Canada Skunks" who fill the air with fragrance. this is what they call the Lightning Train I cannot tell what for it stops at almost every House and the only difference there seems to be between this and our roads is that the Houses are not so thick.

13
Whew what a country! Timber 2 feet high to as high as you can see. here and there a Hut supposed to be inhabited from the fact that a small stream of smoke is seen issuing from a gimlet-hole in the roof. arrived at Hamilton at 1 1/4 O'clock P.M. stopped and took something they called dinner but it would not pass for anything more than an apology in Massachusetts. at 4 1/2 O'clock in London stopped to bait?. can't call it anything else. 9 O'clock P.M. at Windsor just across the river from Detroit. hustle about and get on board the Ferry-Boat and in 10 minutes we are in Detroit just in season for the Cars -  "All Abord" and we are off on a night's ride. try to sleep. no go. some talking. some snoring. Babies squalling. Doves squeaking. all this with my being tired. Sleepy. nervous. unclear &c make it rich in the extreme.
Wednesday Jany 16th
Daylight appears and with it Michigan Woods. Swamps. Virginia fences. Shanties prairies. &c which sort of wake up my ideas and I feel encouraged. 1 O'clock P.M. at Chicago 1013 miles from Boston. Train starts for Rock Island at O'clock. conclude to go. jump aboard, are off for Rock Island this road runs through some of the most splendid prairie land in the western country extending as far as the eye can reach as level almost as a House floor. in some parts a little rolling just enough to make it look beautifully. then on the river banks very high bluffs which seem to rise almost perpendicularly. leaving a narrow strip on each side of the river of very rich farming land. arrived at Rock Island at 10 O'clock P.M. and stopped at the Island City Hotel one of the best Hotels west of Chicago. had a room with a Gentleman from New York who is going east after his family having located at Davenport just across the river he gives a glowing description of the country about here

14
Thursday Jany 17th
After breakfast I started out in search of Howard Morse?. find him at the only Music Store in the City. very glad to meet and after the usual congratulations we start on a lark about town cross over the Mississippi on the ice to Davenport to call on Mr Corbin? a friend of D W Wilerx? to whom I am indebted for a letter of introduction. as ill luck will have it he has just gone East on a visit which puts an end to my prospects in that quarter. after looking about this truly? fascinating place which is situated on the west bank of the river on the gently rising land between the river and the very high bluffs back which protect it from the cold winds in the Winter. It contains some 10,000 inhabitants. almost all kinds of business are carried on here. some Manufacturing, Flouring Mills, Foundries, unclear. I am told that one concern in the Flouring business cleared last year $20,000. on the whole I think this city to be a very interesting place. cross back to Rock Island which is also a business like place although I prefer Davenport. great gift concert this evening got up by Morses'? employer buy a Ticket. at 7 1/2 O'clock a Polka is played on the Piano by German performer then the drawing commenced and after waiting about one hour Morses'? and my numbers are called and we draw. bunch of Toys. Morse is going to Du Buque? tomorrow and as I should not be able to see Mr Corbin? think I will go with him as I am tired of travelling alone.
Friday Jany 18th
Start from Rock Island at 6 1/2 O'clock A.M. for La Salle at which place we connect with the Illinois Central R.R. 83 miles from Rock Island. arrived at 11 O'clock and wait until 1 P.M. for the Train from the South. this road runs through beautiful Prairie country. interspersed here and there with a fine flourishing Village to Freeport. here it comes into the mountainous country

Which looks romantic in the extreme. we reached Dunleith which is the terminus of the Rail Road. at 8 1/2 O'clock P.M. here we took a crack for the City Hotel and crossed the river on the ice to Du Buque? where we find a friend of Morses' at the Hotel and take rooms with him. after taking a little supper feeling very tired we retired.
Saturday Jany 19th
After breakfast we started out on a unclear in the midst of a Snow Storm. Du Buque? is a City situated 188 miles from Chicago on the West bank of the Mississippi on a little Peninsula or strip of land between the river and the bluffs. the level land is about half a mile wide and all the business in on the main Street which is about 2 miles long. there are some fine Stores here which are rented at enormously high rates higher than Boston or New York say $1000. for a single room on the first floor. how they do business at a profit is a mystery to me. I suppose however that they bleed the country folk who are obliged to come from a great distance to trade. after examining thoroughly the business part of the city, we took a stroll up on the bluffs which rise to a height of several hundred feet above the river. in some places almost perpendicular. there are some very fine residences. but I should not like the fun of getting up and down. we went out on a rock? that seems to hang almost over the city. in fact it does hang over some buildings though I think they are not dwellings. from this point is one of the most romantic sights that can be imagined. standing several hundred feet above the river one can see every part of the City and in the Summer when the Boats are flying? up and down it must be charmingly beautiful. after dinner we walked across the river to Dunleith which is the terminus of the Illinois Central RR. this company have a splendid Freight Depot build of Stone and are now a passenger Depot a large, commodious, and substantial structure.

16
opposite the Argyle House a splendid Hotel built also by the R.R. Co. - these are all the [sic] there seems to be here. - walk back to DuBuque and call on Mr. Lull a music teacher from the Green Mountain Institute at Woodstock Vermont where Lewis Charles Fanstina and Annie went to School. - purchased some stationery and intend writing them tomorrow - Morses' prospect of a Store here is rather slim - and he thinks he will go to Chicago next and see what is going on there. - all right for to-night. -
Sunday Jany 20th

   Rather stormy and cold.  write a letter to Newman and one to Rock Island and hark! the bell rings for dinner. - I'm there. - goodness, what an appetite it seems as though I could eat enough. - after dinner write another letter to R. G. Adams Burlington Iowa - too late to go to church. rather strange for me to stay two Sundays in succession but I think I shall stand it. - 6 o'clock tea time appetite good again - Hotel Keepers don't make much on my board I'll bet. - after tea went to church. - sermon very good. preached by Rev Mr. Phelps - music good - melodeon played by Mr. Lull - singing very fair. - Some very fine Young Ladies almost sighed for an introduction to one of them that I might pass an hour or two in their company - but am obliged to go Home alone and sneak off to bed. -

Monday Jan 21st

   Felt very unwell this morning, took rather too much Pectoral last night. - toward noon felt better and at dinner eat quite hearty. - played chequers for diversion - took a walk down to the Julien House a much better Hotel than the one where we stopped - tea is ready and I am quite "Sharkish" - after tea went to an Auction, where a German Auctioneer was making all manner of sport of the bidders - to the Hotel and retire -

17
Tuesday Jany 22d

   At 6½ O'clock after paying our bills at the meanest Hotel we have been in yet we start for Chicago - go as far as Freeport on the Illinois Central RR distance about 60 miles - here we take the Galena and Chicago line which passed through some very flourishing towns - one in particular Rockford a most delightful place. - at 5 o'clock after rather a hard days ride we are in Chicago - stop at the Briggs Hotel the first Hotel in Chicago kept by messrs French & Floyd - Mr Floyd was formerly  a conductor on the Norfolk County Rail Road afterward Superintendent of the Boston and New York Central and proved himself equally acceptable as a Landlord. - we find that he has just gone to Boston, so that we shall not see him. -

Wednesday Jany. 23d

   Arose at the early hour of 8 o'clock and after sitting down to splendid breakfast we take a stroll about the city. - visit the music [?Warerooms?] as Morse wishes to go to work - does not succeed very well. - all supplied at present. - Chicago is a very large and thrifty city, and probably growing faster than any other inland city in the country - it seems alive with business of all kinds - there are some elegant Wholesale Stores down next the river. and then come the retail Stores which are equally as good particularly on Lake Street which will compare very favorably with Boston or New York - but the Streets and sidewalks are decidedly behind the times. there is great danger of ones falling at almost every crossing. and in the night as they are covered with ice I consider it extremely dangerous.  there is a fast sett of people here who I should think from appearance mean to "go it while they're young". - Sleighing is pretty good here now and the way the Horses are put through is a caution. - fast Horses, and fast Women. seem to be the leading articles here. - in the evening we visited Higgins Bros music store and heard them gas awhile. - mercy to hear these western people talk one would think that

18
theirs was only place in the world fit to live in. or of any importance. - they are the most conceited humbugs imaginable it makes no difference what city or town you go into, what may be its facilities for business, or what advantages it has in any respect, it is all the same.  its the only place fit for man to live in. - at 9 o'clock we retire having made up my mind to keep good hours
Thursday Jany 24th

   After breakfast we start out to see the rest of the city as we shall probably leave here tomorrow - found a Boston boy at Greens' music store by the name of Anguera who showed us about the city for two hours or more. - we walked through that part of the city which is used mostly for Dwellings. - there are a great many very nice Houses built of Marble. Brick. Wood &c which will compare favorably with the eastern part of the country in the evening we went to the only Theatre in the city - and Small Potatoes at that - Yankee Locke and his wife are performing here now and they are the only attraction there is. - they perform their comicalitic very well allthough Yankee does not begin with Warren of the Boston Museum. - at 11 o'clock the performance ends and we walk back to the Hotel not wishing to witness any more such performances of the Kind in Chicago. - decide to stop over another day. -

Friday Jany 25th

   Went to the Post Office, expecting a letter from Burlington - but was disappointed and shall now leave Chicago tonight and let Burlington go as I think a situation a little farther South where one can go about without shivering will be more agreeable to me.  it is very cold here in Chicago and I should dislike to live here especially in the winter. - and in no account would I change from Eastern to Western Society if I were to judge from what I have thus far seen. - O dont I dread this

nights ride - I am tired and sick of riding in the cars and especially in the night. it is a most disagreable task for me now, however I am in hopes to find a stopping place soon where if I live as well as they do here at the Briggs House I shall soon grow so fat that my good friends in So Dedham will not know me. - "By the way" this Briggs House is just the best Hotel I have been in since I left Home.  they have the most obliging sett of officials about the House and a Stranger is sure to be well cared for. -  6 PM Morse has just come in and says he has a prospect of a job with Green.  consequently we shall not leave tonight as we were calculating says he shall know tomorrow about it. - may get my letter yet. who knows! - went out after ten and rolled 3 strings of "ten Pins" with Morse. - get beat every time. - smat [sic] business that. - home and rolled to bed. -
Saturday Jany 26th

   What a city for Fires. - there is an alarm almost every hour. but I do not [sic] on any very serious Fires. - they seem to have an efficient  Department consisting of some very splendid machines well manned. - Hook and Ladder companies &c - besides they have a steam Fire Engine which I hear the Firemen do not like very well - with all these facilities I should think  there would be very little danger of a large conflagration. - here we are waiting for Morse to decide whether he will stop or not. - he is what the Western folks would call a regular One Horse team. it seems as though he never would make up his mind to anything. - he must look and look and talk and guess. and then he dared not risk it. - Oh, Fiddle in such a fellow - I shall wait much longer for him. - I cant afford to stay here at the rate of $2.50 per day to accomodate him or for the sake of his company. although it is rather more pleasant to have an acquaintance to travel with. - if he does not conclude what to do by Monday I shall leave. - if he stops here I shall go to Burlington as I have some

20
acquaintance there and should enjoy myself better than among all Strangers. - 9 oclock Morse has not come in from Greens' yet I should think they might come to terms in the course of 1856.  by the aspect of things at present. - Morse is never ready to go to bed and of course never ready to get up but enough of this strain for tonight. - see how he progresses tomorrow. -
Sunday Jany 27th

   Arose at the early hour of 9 O'clock - did not go to church in the morning. - in the afternoon we heard an excellent Sermon at one of the Presbyterian Churches. - the Pastor seemed to be trying to revive the good work in his church - took for his text "Adam where art thou" and applied it to all. - to the church he said where are the 75 members of this church? - we only get from 30 to 50 at our prayer meetings - to the balance he would say "Where art thou." - to the Sinner he would say thou art like a shipwreck. - the life Boat is sent to your rescue, - you still cling to that frail deck. - unless you give up and get on board the lifeboat you will certainly perish.  all he wanted he said was to impress on the minds of all present the necessity of asking themselves the question "Where are we" - to find out our true position and if not in the way of serving the Lord in carrying on his work here on the earth let us strive in the future to be faithful and zealous, that we reap the reward of well done in the sight of the Lord. - the singing by a choir of 8 members was most excellent  the best I have heard since I left Home - almost as good, even as at South Dedham. - after tea Morse says let us go again this evening but I thought once on a stormy Sunday would do. - besides I wished to have a little talk with Geo. P. Floyd who says he is going to open a Hotel in Quincy Illinois about 250 miles South West from Chicago. - I believe that this is the best paying business that can be done in the western country. the Hotels are full to

21
overflowing. - they charge the highest price for board &c and their provisions do not cost them one half so much as they do in the eastern country. - If I only had the Tin I would like to try it. - although I suppose it needs experience to enable one to please all kinds of people which must be done in order to gain popularity. -
Monday Jany 28th

   Still awaiting Morses' motion, he thinks he shall decide tonight "good gracious" if he does I shall be glad for I am getting tired of loafing here. - I must either have something to do or else push along. - went to the Post office but did not get a letter it is very strange. - one week ago last Sunday I wrote 3 letters 2 of them had only about 200 miles to travel yet I not got an answer to either of them. - Uncle Sams' men must be very slow that they cannot carry a letter 200 miles and get an answer back in 8 days - in New England a letter would go that distance and back in 3 days. but the West is just in that ratio. behind in everything. according to my ideas - in everything did I say?  No! they are ahead in a few things such as swearing, drinking, gambling cheating &tc - in fact in all the cities I have been in the grog shops are as thick or as near as every other door - and every Hotel has a bar though as a general thing they are not in sight, but easily found. - which from my observation I should say were well patronised. and of course when liquor is indulged in so freely then evils which always follow in its train are prevalent. - you seldom hear a western man speak without an oath. and if he trade with you in any shape his aim is to swindle you. - I mean now the trading or speculating class. - I doubt not the merchants here deal honorably for in fact nearly all of them are eastern people who have not yet got into the cheating business. - yet I think they will be obliged to cheat or Smash up which seems to be a very fashionable way of doing business. - as it seems to me that business of many kinds will be over done in the cities which are springing up west of the Mississippi in Iowa, Minesota,[sic] and also in Wisconsin - there seems to be a perfect rush -

22
from the east of young men who are anxious to get into business. who desire to locate in these new cities, and my opinion is that very few of them will ever get rich in pursuing a legitimate business. - all those who are rich here had made their money in the rise of property, which in fifteen years has increased to an almost incredible degree. - Land which then was worth only government prices sells now readily for from $500 to $10,000 per acre. - who could not be rich under such circumstances - perhaps there is just as good a chance in the new cities that are springing up farther West at any rate if I had plenty of the ready I would try it. - or I think that lending money would do as the legal rate of interest is from 6 to10 per cent and you can get readily from 2 to 3 per ct a month with real estate security which is a little ahead of eastern rates. although I think the risk somewhat greater among regular shavers than among honest people. -  you are obiged [sic] to be on the lookout or some sharper will have the advantage of you.
Tuesday Jany 29th

   Oh dear.  Morse has not decided yet about stopping here. if he does not today I shall leave him in his glory - I can't afford to say any longer for the sake of his company however agreable it might be. - 5 o'clock Morse has decided to stop and I shall go to Burlington. - they say it is doubtful whether there will be a train tonight on account of the Snow. - and I do not wish to get caught on the Prairie in a Snow Storm. so I will stop over night and see what the prospect is in the morning. - 

Wednesday Jany 30th

   After breakfast took a carriage to the Depot and wait until 2 hours after the regular time 11 o'clock start but we are doomed to be delayed as there are 3 trains due here now. after starting and stopping and backing an almost inumerable number of times we reach the Junction about 30 miles from Chicago where we took wood and water then went along very well for about 50 miles when we were stuck fast in the Snow about a [sic] high as the

23
car windows - having 30 Irishmen on board with shovels - they were set to work and after backing. starting. and twitching about for an hour we were clear again. - reached Mendota which is at the Junction with the Illinois Central road and about 88 miles from Chicago at 5 ½ oclock where we are cooly told that the train will go no farther tonight. as there are already 3 trains frozen  up within 3 miles of this Depot - decidedly rich this. - well our motto is "make the best of everything" so we just walk into the Rail Road House owned by the co and probably erected for such occasions as these and registered for a nights lodging. - they have just rigged up a big snow-Plow and are starting off to dig out the Trains. - I am told that all the roads are blocked with Snow. it seems queer to me that a little snow not more than a foot deep should stop the cars. but the reason is it blows for miles across the Prairie and fills up every cut and hollow full and very solid so that it has to be shovelled out. - "What a country" at 6 ½  Oclock took tea. - Scraped acquaintance with a Gentleman who keeps a Hotel at Wilmington Ill who was going to Burlington - seemed to be a a nice fellow - took him for a bed fellow there being no possible chance of getting a single bed - at 8 Oclock we retire to enjoy the sweets of balmy sleep.
Thursday Jany 31st

    Arose at 7 Oclock - very early for this lazy country - am told that the trains nearest here were dug out - that a train went to Chicago at 2 O'clock this morning and that we may possibly get away this afternoon - visited a flouring mill which is just going into operation - got well floured over and that was about all as they were not in full operation and I could not see how flour was made - Mendota is quite a thriving Village - I am told that 2 years ago there were but 3 or 4 houses here - now I should judge there were 200 or more - 4 or 5 small Hotels quite a number of Stores &c and it being at the junction of two important Rail Roads must be in a short time an important

24
place - yet it must be a very cold place in the winter as there is no timber land to break off the cold winds which sweep over the vast prairies that extend as far almost as the eye can reach - at 2½ Oclock P.M. started for Burlington not expecting to get through "but we did though" - the road from Mendota runs through a great diversity country - through Prairies, and deep cuts over Hills deep ravines high precipices &c - here and there a little Settlement of a house or two destined no doubt at some day to be great cities - and some larger, fine looking Villages of older growth - - after rather a tedious ride we reached Burlington at 9½ O'clock in the evening - not expecting a train there were no carriages at the Depot and we were compelled to walk over on the ice which was rather a cold job however we got across and stopped at the Wightman House where I got a good bed, "a luxury indeed". -
Friday Feby 1st

    got up at 7 oclock - looked across the street and almost opposite I saw the sign of my friend R. S. Adams - after breakfast went over to his Store and found him and his son. after the normal salutations we had a glorious chat. - Mr. A. took me to his nephew who keeps a few boarders and found accommodations - took dinner - went back to the Store again - had an introduction to several gentlemen one from St. Louis a Mr. Davenport formerly of Hopkinton Mass. who very kindly invited me to call on him if I came to St. Louis. - another Mr Green of the firm of Green Thomas & Co. Bankers, also a Doctor Barrett and others too numerous to mention - it is so cold that I cannot look about much today - "Goodness gracious" if my seat at the  table is not directly opposite two "School Marms" [?] ahead - only wait and get an introduction and then"go it" - Mr. Robinson my boarding master seems to be a very nice man. he is from the state of Maine - has been here something over one year. likes very well - does not wish to go back again - so much for the day -

25
Saturday Feby 2d

    Cold as Greenland - cant go out today - loaf about Mr A's store chatting with him and hearing him tell stories for which he is noted besides he is posted on almost any subject - but he is a fiery man quickly excited. and as quickly over it - a most hospitable host. - he desires my to come out to his house tomorrow with his Son and a Nephew of his who I room with and have some music. his Son is called the best Flutist in the State and his Daughter plays the Piano her husband is also a musician but unless it moderates some it will be a hard case to walk a mile and not freeze ones ears or nose or hands - but we shall see

Sunday Feby 3d

   Arose at 9 O'clock - took breakfast although I could hardly hit my mouth my hand shook so with the cold - the mercury this morning was 20 degrees below zero yet it does not much colder than zero weather in Boston - wrote 2 letters one to my Mother and one to my dear friend Lewis - which is more pleasant than going to Church when all nearly all are strangers to me - and especially in such cold weather. - at 8 Oclock Boarders are off to church and I being cold and sleepy post off to bed. -

Monday Feby 4th

    Cold as ever but it looks as though it might be warmer tomorrow. - went into the Commercial College and got a circular of terms &c as I think if I stay here I shall attend a few weeks - after dinner went to the only music Store in Burlington. found that the young man who tends is a Boston boy and I shall another place where I can pass some of my leisure hours. -  It is Election here today of city officers - does not seem to be much excitement my friend Adams is a candidate for alderman but does expect to be elected - went to see Mr Parsons son-in-law of Mr Adams - he seems to be a very nice young man

26
Tuesday Feby 5th
After breakfast went to the Store as usual and had a social chat -- then to the commercial College and commenced a course of Bookkeeping -- the School room is a queer looking place compared with ours at home -- an old. large. cold. rough room and such weather as is almost impossible to keep it comfortable -- I took a desk very near the Stove and made out to Keep quite comfortable -- after dinner I went with Frank Cheney to walk up South hill so called then back to school. --
Wednesday Feb 6th
Another Snow Storm. and no train in yet. and of course no mail -- if I was not attending school. I think it would be lonesome. or rather tiresome. loafing about here but I have made so many acquaintances since I have been here. that I have plenty of places to call and could manage not to be. lonesome. I think. --
Thursday Fb'y 7th
It is a beautiful day rather warmer than yesterday--if this is only holds a few days it will be very pleasant--There is a train in from Chicago and I am in hopes to get a letter from home--went to School this forenoon and made very good progress I begin to be quite interested in double entry Bookkeeping. there was an Engineer killed in the railroad across the river yesterday in a singular manner. he was standing in the doorway of a freight car while it was in motion. when going through a snowbank which had not been shovelled quite wide enough -- the door was closed by the Snow, and his head was caught between the door and casing and horribly crusshed--killing him instantly -- very shocking occurrence.--
Friday Feby 8th
There was a large Fire last night about 12 1/2 O'clock the alarm was raised and the fire found to proceed from the Stores on Jefferson Street occupied by my boarding master Mr Robinson

27
as a tailoring establishment and a Mr. Sommers as a Hat and Cap store which was entirely consumed with their contents--it being very frosty the Engine the only one in the City could not be put in operation for half an hour--and the prospect of a large conflagration was at one time almost certain--as the next store adjoining was a drug store and the only thing that saved it was that the roof was covered with snow--after the Engine was got in operation the flames were quickly subdued--Mr Robinsons' loss is about $2000. insured for $1000.--Summer' loss $3000. insured $2000. -- Mr Lane the proprietor of the Music Store died at 3 o'clock this morning--have been to School today--we are to have a lecture this evening on commercial law.--
Saturday Feby 9th
Attended the lecture at the College last evening--it was delivered by Ben. Darkin? Esq one of the best Lawyers in the State.--his subject was--Promissory Notes--he merely gave the outlines and at the next lecture will give the detail.--have been to School and am becoming more and more interested as I proceed and hope I shall learn to be a Bookkeeper yet. --the school was dismissed at 4 o'clock. and the scholars went off in search of some sport.--
Sunday Feby 10th
I arose at 7 oclock and after breakfast took a walk about the city for an hour--it is situated on the west bank of the Mississippi on rather uneven land--the business part is on the level land between the river and the bluffs--and the churches, School Houses, and dwelling or unclear on a number of small bluffs or hills. and make a fine appearance--there are some very fine Buildings, which will compare very well with the east--the city contains about 12000 inhabitants. yesterday our landlord met with another misfortune--a boarder by the name of Bennett run off or took Scotch leave, taking with him two coats an overcoat and a Frock with $50. Mr R.

28
is going on after him as he formed out at the Stage office that he took passage for Fairfield at town about 50 miles west yesterday there were 2 accidents on the Rail Road one the explosion of a Boiler of a Locomotive. that was just leaving the Depot with a freight Train--the boiler exploded and tore the Engine and tender all to pieces but strange to say although there were 3 persons on the Engine not one was killed or seriously injured. -- the other case was the breaking of a wheel of the under which detached the Engine from the train--the tender was upset? and thrown some 30 ft from the track leaving the cars on the track -- doing no other damage than smashing the tender. no person injured in this case either. -- yesterday was an eventful day. ----
Monday Feby 11th
Yesterday afternoon Frank Cheney and myself went out to my friend Adams' he lives out of the city about a mile -- it is a very pleasant walk part of the way through the woods which would make it delightful in the Summer -- he has a fine new brick House. and excellent land around it--I should think his family might enjoy life out here very well.--Mr Parsons and wife (Mr Adams daughter) live with him--Mrs Parsons is a very fine appearing lady quite a Piano player and singer--we had quite a concert--Mr Adams and Mr Parsons sung Bass Mr Cheney tenor. Abraham played the alto on his Flute and Mrs Parsons sung the treble and played the Piano-- after tea Cheney decided to go back to the city--. they would not let me go--I must stay overnight so I passed the evening with Mr A and wife in a very pleasant manner--in the morning he had the Horse (a very fine one) harnessed and we rode to the city in grand style--I enjoyed this visit very much.--
Tuesday Feb 12th
Nothing of importance happened yesterday I went to School and made very good progress.--this morning I was at 6 o'clock the first time

29
I have been so early since I came here--the weather is cold again and signs of Snow. P.M. snows a little.--there was no train in last night. for what reason I know not--it could not be on account of snow for it has been thawing for 2 or 3 days and I should not think it could drift. -- but I should like to know the reason as I am expecting a letter from Home every mail it is 5 weeks since I left home and have not received a letter yet--that I think is rather hard. -- but with my favorite motto "all for the best" I make out to feel contented. if my letter have only reached home I shall be satisfied. as I doubt not they are as anxious to hear from me as I am to hear from them. our Landlord has returned without the thief the man he followed proved to be a Doctor who lives in Fairfield. this adds still more to his losses which are very severe for him.--he thinks now that the rascal took the cars and went east as he said that he belonged in Cleveland Ohio.--
Wednesday Feby 13th
Pleasant again today and quite warm but no Train in yet--Abraham and Mr Parsons and wife and several others were calculating to start east this morning but were disappointed--they will go in the first Train that starts out--
Thursday Feb-14th
Valentines day--no account made of it here.--arose at 6 oclock and after breakfast took a walk of a mile about town and then according usual custom went to the Store--before going to School--a great many people are wanting to go east but there is no train in yet
Friday Feby 15th
Warm and pleasant today--the Train got in last night and went out this morning so that Abraham and the rest of the folks have started. the snow is thawing quite fast and the prospect is good for a general thaw--

30
Saturday Feby 16th
Quite cold again today and this very disagreeable for me--went to School in the forenoon and after dinner helped Mr H about his books - he wishes me to help him take care of them while Abraham is away which I shall most willingly do--tomorrow will be Sunday and should it be pleasant and I feel in good trim I will go to church with Mr Dalhoff the principal of the commercial College who seems to be very much of a gentleman--
Sunday Feby 17th
arose at 7 oclock and after going through the usual preliminaries of preparing for Church--took breakfast, and then took a long walk.--went to the Post office--did not get a letter--What luck--in the afternoon went out to Mr Adams' and had a pleasant time singing, playing talking until tea time -- after tea came back to the city and went to the Methodist church--it was not a very interesting service and I came home in a sleepy mood and retired.--
Monday Feby 18th
Pleasant day--wrote a letter to my very good friend unclear Day Esq--went to School--nothing of importance to record.--
Tuesday Feb 19th
arose at 6 oclock--took breakfast--then a long walk--helped Mr Adams fix rip his Books--went to School--P.M. snow Storm--Oh dear when will it be Spring--or when will the train bring me a letter--evening--looks as though might be pleasant again tomorrow.--
Wednesday Feb 20th
Warm and pleasant again--such weather I dont see but it is nearly as bad the eastern climate--warm one day and cold the next--but they it will be better soon--fixed up Mr Adams Books--took a walk--after dinner called at the music store and had a chat with the young man (Brother of the Mr Lane that died last week) who is

31
going to carry on the business for the present - went to School until 4 o'clock - could not study very well - took leg bail and started on a walk across the river - found "Mrs. Syppy" so wet and sloshy that I thought it would not pay - turned back and found two class mates in the same fix - we all went up to the Gas works which were in operation 2 days and then frose up - found Capt - who used to board where I do - he showed us around the premises - how gas was made &c - we then seperated and it being nearly tea time    I went to the House - after tea to the College - Mr Adams I find is somewhat inclined to hard stop out West. he even asked me how I would like his business he's getting old and tired of business. and somewhat out of health - but I am not prepared to enter into any arrangements of that kind until I see how my health is to be - I think however that I am improving quite fast. and when I go home I can tell whether I will go into business there or out here. -
Thursday Feb 21st

    a beautifully pleasant day overhead and the streets are beautifully muddy - took a long walk this morning and feel much better for it - did not go to School. - think I am sticking rather too closely - sent off a check to L Andrews & Co New York and one to Osgood & Smith Indianapolis. - he seems to want me to do all his business in this line - P.M. went to school until 4 oclock wrote a letter to a south Dedham friend - had an introduction to a Mr. Ballou who is soliciting aid for a Universalist school in Galesburg - also to N E Bartlett who was formerly from So. Walpole and is acquainted with a great many people in Walpole and Dedham and who seems to be a fine man. -

Friday Feby 22d

   I rose at 5 ½ Oclock and according to a usual custom in the East started off for a walk but was arrested by one of the boarders who said that would not do - that it is considered a dangerous practice. and is almost certain to bring on Fever and Ague

32
cause - a sort of Effluvia or something else rises from the land which is dispersed by the Sun - a great idea it seems to me but I suppose it is all right - P.M. raining very hard - mud increasing in depth and prospect of a general stream -
Saturday Feby 23d

   Pleasant but quite cool - oh such changes hot and rainy yesterday - cold and fair today New England itself cant beat this after all they blow about it - went to School this forenoon but did not get ahead much - had a sort of a headache which made me feel stupid - P.M. went to School until 4 o'clock - then to the music store - had a chat with young Lan - to the store - had another with Mr Adams - took tea and sit in the house the rest of the evening - at 9 Oclock took an upward course and retired to bed. but not to Sleep - the cocks were crowing and dogs barking so that we could not go to sleep till after 12 Oclock - Cheney got up and yelled at them which frightened them into quietude - such a lot of dogs as there are in this city - it is a caution to young folks - one cannot go out without seeing from 1 to 20 dogs. - no wonder Sausages are tough and cheap -

Sunday Feby 24th

   Arose at 8 Oclock - after breakfast went to the Post Office but did [sic] get a letter I begin to think I am not to have one from Home - went to the Episcopal Church - heard a very good sermon - but the ceremony seems to me rather insignificant. however were I accustomed to it I suppose I should like it. - after dinner started out with Mr Dudley thinking to go to Mr Adams' but was so muddy that we backed out - we walked up the Rail Road about a mile just for exercise and passed the remainder of the afternoon in reading talking &c - in the evening went to the Baptist church where I listened to a very good Sermon delivered by the Pastor Mr Johnson - also witnessed the ceremony of Baptism - the subject was a young lady who took the plunge with all the symptom of good faith - after this was over went home and retired

33
Tuesday [sic]  Feby 25th

   another beautiful day and of course abundance of mud so that getting about the streets, on the ugly side-walks and something they call flag stones (but which I think a very poor apology) is about like performing on a slack rope - and I think by the time I am ready to go home I shall be quite a performer-  Journalised and Posted Mr Adams' Books this forenoon P.M. went to School this afternoon but could not study the students were all full of the "Old Harry" or something else and the Principal seemed to have no control over them and at 4 Oclock I gave it up as a bad job -

Tuesday Feby 26th

    a most beautiful day   It seems like spring and were I at home I should expect to hear the Birds singing - but here they have nothing but Prairie chickens and Crows - none of those little birds that cheer the heart in New England - I have finally got a letter from my dear friend Lewis and am full of joy to learn that my friends at home are all well - received a line from Teen and Martha which was very pleasing - the forenooon was spent in School to very good advantage - P.M cloud and looks likely to rain if it should rain for a short time it would make the river snap which would be very agreeable to me for unless I get into some kind of business by the time I get through at the College I shall want to be moving.

Wednesday Feby 27th

    It snowed last night just for variety but I guess it will not make out much - it does beat me - such changes from hot to cold I am not accustomed to even in changeable Masachusetts - P.M. it has cleared away and seems rather pleasant but rather cold for comfort after having a few days so warm. - the longer I stay here the more I am impressed that this is not the place for me to settle - there is system of doing business that I do not like - the chief aim seems to be to make all you can out of everybody. - friend or foe - in regard to the people as social beings I think very favorably of them - they seem to try to make one as happy as possible sparing no pain to make a strangers stay pleasant

34
Thursday Feby 28th

    It snowed again last night - dont it push a fellow to keep track of the Weather though! - did a little business for Mr A - sent a check to How & Cook St Louis - it costs ½ per cent to send funds to St. Louis and only 1 per cent to New York it seems rather inconsistent as the distance is nothing comparitively but I see that I am not posted in financial affairs out West - went to School and made very good progress

Friday Feby 29th

   Arose at 6 oclock and after breakfast took a walk over the South hill - it is the roughest good for nothing place I have to for a long time - up and down. but mostly up until you reach a height of several hundred feet above the river - on the top are two Churches a Seminary and several very respectable looking Houses - after trudging about in the cold  [?] [hom?] I went went [sic] to the Store and did up what business there was to be done - then went to School - after dinner went to the Post Office - but did not get any of the several letters now due me - how provoking - P.M. it snows a little just for a change - there is to be a lecture at the College this evening but as I have a slight headache I shall not go. --

Saturday March 1st

   Spring today - but only in name - the weather is not so spring like as it was two weeks ago - cold and squally - went to School and worked in the Calculator which is rather intricate  but I guess I will master it - shall go out to Mr Adams' tonight - he says he will rig me out a Bath tomorrow which is just what I want - Played BackGammon in the evening until 9 O'clock when Mr A called and we started off through the woods a new route for me - reached the House in due time and after an hours' chat retired to rest. -

Sunday Mch 2d

   arose at [?] O'clock - took breakfast - and the Mr A had some warm water ready and I indulged in a good Bath - the best one I

35
have had since I came from Home - spent the forenoon in reading &c while Mr A. was gone to the city - while sitting here it strikes me that I should like to be in South Dedham today - take a shake hands all around and exchange a few words with kindred and friends - but that cannot be - and I must be contented where I am - and thank Heaven that I am so much better off than Thousands just as deserving but who are frustrated by sickness and other misfortunes over which they have no control - PM Mr Adams has returned - Mr & Mrs Field came out soon after and we had a social chat about our Eastern friends &c - eating Pop corn and Apples until tea time - after tea I started for the city by the same route we came last night - had a hard time traveling over the frosen ground which is as rough as a Blacksmith rasp - got home after a time and sit over the Stove until 8 oclock - retired dreaming of far off loved ones at Home -
Monday Mch 3d

  Not quite so cold, but it is rather too cold for comfort - worked at the Store until I was almost froze - then went to School - made slow progress - have got into the hard part which requires considerable study - but I shall conquer it after a while - after went to the most comfortable place which I occupy in the 24 hours - to Bed

Tuesday Mch 4th

   another cold day but the Sun shines and it seems rather pleasant - went down to Store Posted up the Books wrote a letter to Neuman and then went to School. -

Wednesday Mch 5th

   arose at the usual time and took a short walk. and some breakfast. - went down to the Store and did a little business for Mr Adams then to school - left School at 5 Oclock - found Cheney and we walked over South hill until tea time - after tea we played Back Gammon until 9 oclock -

36
Thursday Mch 6th

    Fair but cooler than yesterday have been a work at the Store writing letters - making bills &c all day not even taking my usual walk. -

Friday Mch 7th

    Worked at the Store until 10 oclock when Mr Adams challenged me to go across the river - having never been over I at once entered into the arrangement and we crossed looked about the Freight Houses and Depot grounds - went into Bartlett & Co commission and Forwarding Office - after looking about to our satisfaction we returned and found that the ice was thawing away fast so as to make it quite wet - after we got back I wrote a letter to Mr Lamson of Fairfield a confidential one - I get considerable of this business to do now - after dinner went to College and Studied an hour which was as long as I could stand it - went with Cheney and walked over the North hill which overlooks the river and must give a fine view when the river is open and alive with Steamboats of all sorts and sizes - after staying as long as we wished I went back to the Store and agreed to tend with Billy this evening and let Mr Adams go home - stayed until 8 oclock - went home and to Bed

Saturday Mch 8th

   Rather cold and prospect of a Snow Storm - Oh dear - I was in hopes that we should not have any more cold weather - have been to School all day, and my teacher tells me that I am about through and that I am pretty well posted in Bookkeeping tomorrow I must write to Lewis and the rest of the folks -

Sunday Mch 9th

   Cold and about an inch of Snow on the ground which fell during the night which will make more muddy travelling - wrote letters to Priscilla, Lizzie, Lewis, Teen & Martha which may bring me some answers in due time

37
after dinner went out to with Cheney - we went out to Dutch Town. - a Village about 1½ miles from the city - settled by the dutch - we went over on the Rail Roads to the North Hill by the Post Office home and sit in the house until tea time - after tea went to a lecture in Marion Hall by O T. Fowler his subject was "Morality in connection with Phrenology" - he argued that mans' highest happines [sic] consisted in the true worship of a supreme being. - that Phrenology clearly demonstrated the existence of such a being - and just in proportion as we have veneration for our Heavenly Father do all our other functions operate and conduce to our happiness - he also argued that Phrenology proves the immortality of the Soul, inasmuch as hope is ever longing for such a state - he drew illustrations of all the different points of his subject an related anecdotes to prove the correctness of them - on the whole it was the best lecture that I have heard for a long time - he is going to give a course of lectures and I think I will attend them - it is very cold the Mercury down to zero. --
Monday Mch 10th

   Very cold this morning mercury below zero - worked at the Store fixing up the Books all day - we heard from Abraham by way of a Mr. Gear who saw him in Boston last Tuesday - they have been having a terrible Storm in New York blocking up all the railroads this side of that point - there has been no mail through from Boston for two weeks that accounts for my not getting any letters Mr Gear thinks there will be one tomorrow - hope so for I am anxious to hear from home - in the evening attended another of Fowlers lectures -  his subject was the perfection of the "Physical System in connection with the intellectual" - he argued that in order to be intellectually great one must first build up the Physical system so that the mental may be properly supported -

38
he  cited numerous cases to show that the mental is often cultivated beyond the Physical and that such persons soon become helpless or fill premature graves - he also made some very interesting remarks in regard to the feeding of children - he recommended giving them very plain food - boiled Wheat he considered the very best food for children or adults -- he also said that to scold a child was a monstrosity - to whip one an outrage - he would rather a child would not mind than to mind through fear -- he says learn them to love you to mind from a love of duty - and they will not disobey - he said the economy of Nature was love - that love was the first principle of that glorious faith which teaches us that if we love God we shall not disobey his laws - the lecture was very interesting to me and I would have missed hearing it for twice the cost and trouble incurred -
Tuesday Mch 11th

 another Snow Storm - it fell to the depth of 3 or 4 inches during last night - loafed about all the forenoon - after dinner went to the College and worked a Problem which only 4 of all the Scholars they have ever had performed - this made the Principal wonder as the whole 4 including myself were what they call out here Yankees or eastern boys - in the evening attended another of Fowlers lectures - his subject was "Love Courtship and Marriage" - he dwelt particularly on the love sentiment as being the cause of more happiness than all other sources put  together - that a person never knew what it was to be happy until they had been in love. - that love would make a hero of a coward - would inspire the man with ambition - he would labor hard and endure almost everything for the sake of one he truly loved - he also dwelt upon the manner of courtship as carried on at the present day - he despised the idea of a young man putting on his Sunday best and calling on Miss Julia who would receive him with a bewitching smile with her Silks and flounces

39
on and thereby both would be deceived - they would not see each other in that true light which is necessary to a happy Union - he held that courting should be done when each are abut their duties as far as practicable and that each should unfold to the other their peculiar ideas of life &c so that neither would say after marriage that they had been deceived - he held also that all these preliminaries must be gone through with before commencing to love - I was very much pleased with his lecture and hope I may profit by it - the public examinations were highly satisfactory to the audience - 
Wednesday Mch 12th

  Fair and somewhat warmer than yesterday loafed this forenoon - went to School this afternoon - in the evening to another of Fowlers lectures - his subject was "Matrimony". he contended that a man should seek a mate of so near the same temperament of himself as possible unless he should be in some point of an excessive turn for instance very nervous. - then he might select one of an opposite in that point - but let each understand it so that it may never lead to differences but be for their mutual benefit - he gave numerous anecdotes to illustrate this point - he blamed the man or woman who would scold their conjugal partner even when there seemed to be cause for it. - as it only widens the gulf between - and turns trifles into mountains - there should be nothing secret - everything of whatever nature should be entrusted to the other - where such feelings existed there you would find true happiness such happiness as can only exist between beings who love each other, and love truly - he made some examinations which were very satisfactory - a very interesting lecture such as the people of Burlington seldom hear -

Thursday Mch 13th

    A kind of mongrel day neither pleasant nor yet very unpleasant - walked over the river just for exercise - took dinner - and loafed about town until tea time - in the evening attended the last of the course of lectures -

40
this lecture was to Gentlemen only - as I have a printed copy of this admirable lecture I will not attempt to write from it -
Friday Mch 14th

   another day of the same sort only a little warmer - have done nothing today but walk and read -

Saturday Mch 15th

   A little more moderate today - attended a court in Marion Hall - the case was this - a returned Californian belonging in Augusta Iowa - left Fort Madison to come to Burlington on the 6th of January last since which nothing has been heard of him - and from some circumstances which have transpired the man who started with him to bring him to Burlington has been arrested and today he was tried or rather witnesses was examined to see if the Justices would indict him - Some 5 o 6 witnesses were examined by the prosecuting attorney going to prove that the defendant and the missing man started together but were not seen together in this city that was pretty nearly that was said on the side - in the afternoon some  10 or 12 witnesses were examined to prove the defendant an honest and trusty man that he brought the missing man safely to Burlington and returned home that afternoon - so that the Justices in less than 10 minutes discharged him - this Court struck me as a sort of Burlesque on a eastern court - the Justice and Lawyers sit around a table squirting tobacco juice over the floor - and it seemed to me that they were acting rather beneath that dignity but I am very glad that I have the opportunity of seeing the contrast between Eastern and Western customs - in the evening went to Temperance lecture in Marion Hall which was filled with the most respectable audience that I have yet seen in Burlington. the lecturer was Levi Leland  I think he is the State lecturer - he is here in order to organize an association the object of which shall be to carry out the Prohibitory Law similar to what is called the Maine Law in the eastern States - he gave an interesting lecture interspersed with some very amusing Stories and anecdotes -

41
he said the Law was doing great good in the country towns and every place where it is enforced and that there would be no trouble in enforcing here would the Temperance people but stand firm - but he was sorry to say that many of them were waning - that they would give utterance to remarks which would fan the opposite party such as "I don't know about this law whether it can be enforced or not" - such expressions give strength to the Liquor party - they say that if the Temperance people have no faith in it why should we have - he stated the fact of the law passing in the Territory of Nebraska - he went over to the seat of Government - the Legislature was then in Session - he succeeded in getting a hearing before that body. and in the evening addressed them - the next day the law was passed without a dissenting vote - he likened the fact of the liquor drinker prating about the law saying they dont care anything about it they can get all the liquor they want, which shows that they are afraid that it will be enforced at no very distant day -  to the Dutchman who had a young Colt which the boys need to ride - but in spite of all they could do he would spring out of the road and throw them off - now says the old Dutchman "let me try it I will break him of that trick - so he told one of the boys to crouch down in a corner ahead of him - and that when he drove by he must jump up and holler Boo - the old man got on and started along when he got opposite the boy jumped up and hollored Boo the colt reared and darted off from under the old man leaving him sitting in the mud - the old man jumped up and says Hans, Hans, dat was too big a Boo - it is so with this law it is rather too big a Boo for them - he likened those who are on the fence ready to jump either way that may offer them the greatest advantage to the Yankee and his horse - a Yankee was travelling on horseback through Kentucky - he had got out of money and thought to sell his horse - he met a Kentuck hunter with his dog and gun - and asked him if he knew of any one who would like to buy a hunting horse   Oh yes says Kentuck

42
you will find no trouble in selling a good hunting horse - but what can your horse do, what is he remarkable for? - Oh says the Yankee when there is any game around he will sit down and remain until the game is secured - well says Kentuck that is remarkable - let us try him so the Yankee started off and soon saw some Rabbits tracks - he pulled the check rein and the horse sit down - Ah says Yankee there are Rabbits here - so the Kentuck started out his dog who soon started a rabbit and he was shot - remarkable says Kentuck what will you take for that horse - $200 says Yankee - done says Kentuck - and paying over the amount Started off - coming to a stream he thought to drive through as he got midway of the stream the horse hold down his head to drink - Kentuck pulled on the rein and the horse as he had been learned to do - sit down the water coming up to the Kentucks neck - tuning to the Yankee he said how is this?  Ho says Yankee he is just as good for fish as he is for game - the lecture was instructive and interesting and from present appearances they will put the Law in operation very soon. -
Sunday Mch 16th

   Arose at 7 oclock and after breakfast and 2 letters from John and Annie Smith very interesting to me as they contained good news - attended the Presbyterian Church where I witnessed the Sacramental ceremony - they had very good singing the best I have heard since I came to Burlington - the Sermon was not very extra rather too Sectarian to suit me - after dinner went with Cheney out to Mr Adams' we found Mr Field and two of his daughters there - we had a sing until tea time - after tea walked back to the city and spent the evening in reading - 

Monday Mch 17th

   A very pleasant day - warm - and it really seems like a Mayday at home - took a walk after breakfast about town as Abraham has got home I shall not have anything to do at the Store - after dinner went to the College and wrote a letter to my good friend E F Gay - balance of the day was loafed away

43
Tuesday Mch 18th

   Another beautiful day - it makes one feel very cheerful to have it so pleasant after such cold weather - took a long walk after breakfast which makes me feel quite chipper - have been loafing about, playing BackGammon &c - in the evening I attended another Temperance lecture in Marion Hall - the lecturer termed it a Physical lecture - he stated the effect produced by taking liquor into the Stomach - it removes the mucous coating or protection of the Stomach - admitting it to the blood and through the blood operates on the System throughout - but especially are its blighting effects witnessed upon the brain - producing idiocy, insanity, and completely wrecking that noble structure the human mind - . the Committee appointed for that purpose reported a series of resolutions expressing strong sentiments in favor of enforcing the Law which are to be acted upon tomorrow evening in Old Lion Church - a very interesting lecture - and the Hall was well filled - this speaks well for the cause. -

Wednesday Mch 19th

   Another beautiful day - our folks are moving to-day into a more aristocratic part of the city - on Washington Street a very good location - it took nearly all day to get the goods moved - and it was 10 oclock in the evening before they got the beds put up - we then had an Oyster Supper - after which we retired to the Sky Parlor and laid ourselves down to rest - dreaming of cobwebs, bed bugs, and a thousand other of the ills that go to fill up lifes' variety -

Thursday Mch 20th

   Fine day.  the ice is beginning to break away from the shore - there are a number of men at work breaking a channel across the river so that the passengers can  come from the rail road to-night - there are several hundred persons witnessing this operation all anxious to see the river open and the ice clear away. -

44
Friday Mch 21st

  Rather cooler today - but the ice is [?wearing?] pretty fast - have been helping Mr Adams' folks take account of stock - watching proceedings at the river - and loafing about to the best advantage. -

Saturday Mch 22d

  Warmer and signs of rain - have been loafing about town. here and there just to pass away the time - evening - it rains and looks like a severe South rain - the Locomotive of the construction train got off the track and the men did not get home until 10 O'clock - they could hardly be told from a pile of mud they were so completely covered. -

Sunday Mch 23d

   Arose at 8 oclock and dressed for Church but did not go - I went to walk 2 or 3 miles and had just turned my steps towards the Church when I saw several hundred persons on the bank of the river and walked down to see what was going on - I found that the ice had started in a body of some 20 [?acres?]  in front of the city. and the people were watching it -. the scene was quite exciting - the roar of the ice grating one piece against another and piling up 10 feet high in some places - together with the joy depicted on every countenance - tend to make one feel (not much like being in church) very happy - it is very warm today - it would be very comfortable in the Sun without a coat on - after dinner went to ride with friend Wyman - we had a very fine Horse and Buggy and rode out several miles on each of the roads leading out of the city - we did not go out far enough to see the Trains but through some very romantic scenery and had a very pleasant ride - in the evening went to the Congregational Church and heard a Temperance Sermon by the Pastor Mr. [?Halter?] from the text "Do thyself no harm" - he gave a glowing illustration of the effect of Liquors on the mind and body and exhorted his congregation to do themselves no harm - to keep themselves pure. and use their influence to keep others so - he regarded the intemperance as the faster Mother of more than half the crime in the world - and should not we as Christians set ourselves at work to rid Society of such a pest. -

45
he particularly exhorted the young - those who will shortly be called to fill the important stations in life to keep themselves from harm that they may be bright and shining examples to which the rising generation that shall come after them will look with pride for counsel and advice - I liked this sermon very well and consider it the duty of every Christian minister to come out boldly and labor for the furtherance of every great reform - one of the greatest of which is Temperance -  I received a letter from Herman stating that the folks are all well - that are living - our Grandmother is dead - she died Mch 11th about sunset - she lived to a very old age (88 years) and dropped away peacefully at last to that blest home where the weary are at rest -
Monday Mch 24th

   Cool but rather pleasant. - have been at work to day helping Mr Robinson build a cook-room on the back part of the house - it serves very well to help pass away the time - in the evening went and taught school for Mr Dalhoff - while he was away to a meeting of some kind - this was new business for me but I got along very well - the scholars behaved well considering the School Master was out -

Tuesday Mch 25th

   Cooler - Snow with a mixture of rain - have been loafing about all day reading, singing, and playing BackGammon. &c -

Wednesday Mch 26th

   Cloudy but not quite so cool as yesterday - was introduced to Ward Lamson a son of old Father Lamson of so much noteriety in the city of Boston.  - he is as eccentric as his father in many respects - he lives in Fairfield in this state - he is rather witty and quick to reply to anything which s advanced - he has been a minister of the M.E. Church but I he is now a sort of come-outer or as his former brethren call him an infidel - reading writing and Gammon constitute the programme of today -

46
Thursday Mch 27th

   Loafing as usual - yet I do [sic] spend my day foolishly - I read useful and instruction books, write, talk, or do almost anything that will [?arouse?] or instruct in order to pass the time pleasantly and not get the blues - in the evening had a frolic with the dress-maker and Mrs Robinson who are very jolly Ladies -

Friday Mch 28th

   Arose at 6 Oclock and after breakfast took a walk of a couple of miles - then sat in the house and read until dinner time - evening - the Prairies are on fire all the time now.  and in the evening it is a grand sight - the sky is lighted from North to South - and from East to West - almost making one think that the world is on fire - and in a cloudy or dark evening it is truly a grand and sublime spectacle - resembling the most brilliant Aurora Borealis -

Saturday Mch 29th

   Pleasant to-day but not quite so warm as I wish it was - loafed about all the forenoon listening to the chattering of an Auctioneer who was selling notions - after dinner went to a Ladies Auction but not seeing any gentlemen there and being rather bashful I withdrew - and went to the music store and spent the afternoon - after tea took a walk with Prof. Dalhoff -

Sunday Mch 30th

    Cold, Cloudy, and unpleasant.  too cold to cold to go to church - sit in house all day reading the Bible and a newspaper sent me from a friend at Home - the paper was got up by the Baptist Society and sold at their Levee in Harlstroms' Hall - it contained a Temperance tale by Mr Chaplin - statistics and description of South Dedham - report of the stock market money matters - suggestions of improvements - Jokes - Riddles - Advertisements of the various kind of business of the Village - and the variety which usually characterizes a country newspaper - it was quit a treat for me - being cold after tea I dispensed with going to Church and went to bed -

47
Monday Mch 31st

   Warmer and much more pleasant than yesterday - Wrote a letter to my good friend [?] Day - remainder of the day was passed in the usual manner - I had a very singular dreamed last night - I dreamed that the Cars ran off the Viaduct at Canton - all the cars went down into the water - the Bells were rung in So. Dedham and there was a terrible time - consternation was depicted on every countenance - so deeply was this dream impressed on my mind that I take the trouble to record it. -

Tuesday April 1st

   The first day of April and I saw the greatest fool  game this morning this morning that ever I have seen - the women of the House fooled every boarder - the[sic] put in the Bowls in place of Sugar, Salt, - and they had Fritter cakes stuffed with cotton - and slap jacks seasoned very highly with cayenne pepper - all of which were intended as traps for the unsuspecting boarders not one of which escaped - they all fell victims to one or more of the snares - and we had a jolly time at the breakfast table - spent the day in the usual way -

Wednesday Apr 2d

   It rained and blew very hard last night - a Steamboat landed and is discharging her cargo this morning which makes the City look more business like than it has before since I came here - went to the College and tried to learn the art of marking cards - it is more of a trick than I had any idea of - it will require a great deal of practice in order to do it well -

Thursday Apr 3d

   Rather cooler and prospect of fair weather - loafed about all day - in the evening went to the music Store with Cheney and some music was the consequence -

48
Friday Apr 4th

   Nothing on the programme today but loafing - which is done with my usual promptness and despatch -

Saturday Apr 5th

   Quite a serious accident happened to Mrs Parsons last evening - she with another lady and Mr Adams' hired man were riding into the city - as they were coming down College hill, the Horse became unmanageable and ran - Mrs. P jumped out of the carriage and was very seriously injured - she was insensible during the night but the Physician thinks she is better this morning and that she will recover - after Mrs. P jumped out the man followed suit leaving the other lady alone in the carriage - which upset as it struck the railroad track at the crossing - she however very fortunately escaped with a few trifling bruises - the man escaped without any injury whatever except being frightened to death "Paddy fashion" - this morning there 2 Steamers at the Levee discharging their cargoes which consisted of all kinds of mdse from the east - - saw some Dutchmen who were digging a cellar back a Horse & Cart down the embankment into the hole which was about 6 feet deep - this was a most awkward piece of business - after laying down some planks they finally succeeded in getting him out - anything for excitement -

Sunday Apr 6th

     Howard Morse arrived in town last night and today in company with young Lane we went to the Presbyterian Church and listened to a Sermon by an aged and venerable minister in the cause - he prophecied in regard to the Millenium - he supposed that the present date of the world was the pouring out of the last drops of the Sixth Vial spoken of in Revelation - he stated that he prophecied in the beginning of the present war in Europe that all that would be accomplished would be establishment of civil and religious liberty in the Turkish empire - he considered this to be the last but one that would ever occur - that within 5 years would commence

49
the greatest revival the world ever knew - the Jews would return to their native country and would be converted to Christianity - that then would commence the last great war - all the Papal powers would combine against the Christians - but God would deliver his people and cause their enemies to quarrel and fight among themselves until all that were not converted to Christianity would be exterminated - and the whole world should come to the knowledge of the Lord - and be his people forevermore - in the evening we went to the Congregational and listened to a Sermon from the text - "Love the Lord your God with all your heart and your neighbor as yourself" he preached a good sermon the best I ever heard from a minister of that persuasion the singing was very fair -
Monday Apr 7th

   A most beautiful day warm enough to go without a coat - walked around with Morse all the forenoon - he is going to Galesburg to-night - see Morse off in the cars and then went to the college and had a chat with Dalhoff

Tuesday Apr 8th

   Warm but cloudy and some signs of rain - the Levee has been in active use today for Steamers have stopped to discharge freight - which has kept me quite busy in connection with my other duties

Wednesday Apr 9th

   Pleasant again today - loafing about as usual -
   What word may be pronounced quicker by adding a syllable to it - An. Quick. -
   Why is a spendthrifts purse like a thunder cloud 
      An. Because it is always Lightning. -
    When will water stop running down hill
       An. when it gets to the bottom -
   What is it that you must Keep after you have given it away
       Ans. - Your word -

50
Thursday Apr 10th

    Another beautiful day which has been spent in reading, writing and loafing -

Friday Apr 11th

    Very warm - it seems like June weather - there was a Thunder Shower last night with some rain - and there has been some little spatters to-day - and some Thunder - it seems odd to me to have thunder showers in April - in the evening went to Marion Hall to hear Dr Loomis lecture on Psychology it was a decent lecture but did not begin with Dr. Cutters lectures -

Saturday Apr 12th

   Cooler to-day and sign of a Storm - spent this day in the usual manner -

Sunday Apr 13th

   Fair again - and warmer - went out to Mr Adams' with Cheney - and found the invalids all getting better - after dinner went down on the Levee and saw 2 Steamers land - several hundred people - a dog fight - some boys pitching coppers - quite a variety for Sunday - sit in the house the remainder of the day - heard an anecdote of a man who had been listening to a very dull discourse he remarked that everything went well especially the audience -

A codfish breakfast and an India Rubber Coat 'tis said will keep a man dry all day -
Monday Apr 14th

   Showery today but rather pleasant after all - in the evening went to a concert by the Blakeley family - it was very good for this part of the country. -

Tuesday Apr 15th

   Not very pleasant and not much going on except another concert by the Blakeleys this evening -

51
Wednesday April 16th

   Quite pleasant - nothing to record - the usual variety -

Thursday Apr 17th

   Loafing about as usual -  there has been several Steamboat arrivals discharging large quantities of freight - which makes the Levee look business like indeed -

Friday Apr 18th

     Arose at  6 Oclock and after breakfast took a long walk which was very invigorating the air was cool but very clear - and the Sun shone in all its brilliancy - the greatest difficulty here now is the dust which rises in clouds so that one can hardly keep their eyes open - they do not have all the modern improvements for sprinkling and sweeping the streets which are used in our eastern cities - and which contribute so largely to their beauty and healthiness - the remainder of the day was spent in reading writing &c -

Saturday Apr 19th

   Nothing worthy of note - to-day - in the evening went to a concert given for the benefit of the Blakeley family it passed off with great eclat -

Sunday Apr    20th

   Arose at 7 oclock took breakfast and then walked up the river - came back and finished reading the New Testament which I commenced since I came to Burlington - after dinner took another walk and then commenced reading the life of Amos Lawrence which I shall finish at the first favorable opportunity as I think it worthy the perusal of every young man - after tea took a walk with friend Lane - we had a very pleasant time viewing and discussing the Scenery &c  - on whole I have passed a very pleasant Sunday -

52
Monday Apr 21st

   a very pleasant day - in the morning I went fishing with a class-mate from Keokuk - we had "Fisherman's luck - neither of us caught even so much as a bite this rather lowered my ambitiion for this kind of sort - in the evening took a walk up the river with Prof Dalhoff - this closed the entertainments of the day. -

Tuesday  Apr 22d

   Nothing going on to day - - I give below a copy of a letter sent to my good friend Lyman Smith Esq -

Being on the eve of starting from this to native land, 
(That's the point that I now wish that you should fully understand) 
I wish to make my promise good to you, and I'm in time.  
This just makes out my number which you know was Fiftynine. 
And first I'll treat of health, and strength, and spirits (rather high) 
All other things of less import.  I'll tell you bye and bye. 
my health is good, and much improved, since the time you saw me last.  
My strength, I'm getting Samson like, and flesh, I'm gaining fast.  
My Spirits high, my thoughts just now I think inclined to roam.  
But the reason I presume to be - because I'm going home -
I think of friends, and kindred, - of all those Ladies fair.  
I feel and trust in Providence that I shall soon be there,  
Kind friend, since last we parted, and shook each others hand, 
I've travelled eighteen hundred miles through this great Yankee land.  
And sights, and wonders, of all kinds have passed before my eyes.  
Which led me to reflections that I hope may make me wise. 
I've seen "Niagara Falls [?Mam?]" - and heard the mighty roar 
of the water s as they rush down where  - Sam Patch - in days of yore, 
"Tis said did take that fatal leap - and ne'er was heard of more. 
I've seen the great Suspension Bridge - that mighty work of man.  
Which forms a grand connecting link - "Tween Vic and Uncle Sam. 
It makes one feel as they ride on - high in the air suspended - 
That should the smallest wire give out - their days on earth were ended  
From thence I took the great R.R. that runs through Vic's domain  
Where her most loyal subjects do her royal state maintain.  
The cars were filled with Bloody Dutch - and French Cannes by scores.  
and emigrants from every port - along our eastern shores.  
The sights and wonders here beheld - seemed not to please my eyes  
But made more than e'er before - a monarchy despise - 
The point when next I landed - was a city called Detroit.               
I know not what 'tis noted for great deed or high exploit

53
I jumped into the cars again - at the sound of "All aboard"
This was the famous night train - and soon the people snored -
I threw myself into a seat - and tried to do "just so"
The doors the creaked and babies squalled and "Troth" it was "no go"
As morn appeared I felt releived - that the country I might see -
But Swamps and timber lands quite vast, was all there seemed to be
At last log cabins hove in sight - and Prairie vast and grand
Which almost made me think at times - I was in desert land -
